div.head: MEDITATIONS And di≈øqui≈øitions upon the Sixth P≈øalme.
div.p: O My ≈øoule, what is it thou ha≈øt done? ha≈øt thou beene ≈øtriving with the Angell, about the bodie of Mo≈øes? For why el≈øe ≈øhould≈øt thou bee afraid of the Angels imprecation to Sathan, when hee ≈øtrove with him about it, The Lord rebuke thee? Certainly either the Angel was very milde in his imprecation, or thou art very ≈øharp in thy deprecation. But O wretch that I am! If Sathan de≈øerved rebuking for ≈øtriving with an Angel; how much more do I de≈øerve it, for ≈øtriving with the Creator of Angels? and not about taking away the body of Mo≈øes, but about taking away the glory of his holy Name? For ≈øuch, and ≈øo execrable are my ≈øinnes, that through them, the holine≈ø≈øe of Gods glorious name is bla≈øphemed among the Gentiles. And have I not ju≈øt cau≈øe then to feare that he will, and therefore ju≈øt cau≈øe to pray, that he will not, Rebuke me in his anger, nor cha≈øten mee in his heavy di≈øplea≈øure.

But though rebuking were an imprecation to Sathan, yet to mee it is not ≈øo, ≈øeeing I doe not more de≈øerve it, then I need it; as I de≈øerve it for my ≈øin, ≈øo I need it for my amendment: for without rebuking, what amending? what amending indeed without thy rebuking? For alas, the fle≈øh flatters mee, the world abu≈øeth mee, Sathan deludes mee; and now O God, if thou al≈øo ≈øhould≈øt hold thy peace, and wink at my follies, whom ≈øhould I have? Alas, whom could I have, to make mee ≈øen≈øible of their foulene≈ø≈øe. If thou ≈øhould≈øt not tell mee, and tell me roundly, I went a ≈øtray, how ≈øhould I ever, alas, how could I ever be brought to returne into the right way? To thy rebuking therefore I humbly ≈øubmit my ≈øelfe; I know thou intende≈øt it for my amendment, and not for my confu≈øion; for my conver≈øion, and not for my ≈øubver≈øion: It may be bitter in the ta≈øting, but is mo≈øt comfortable in the working: hard perhaps to dige≈øt, but mo≈øt ≈øoveraigne, being dige≈øted: Yet I cannot endure thou ≈øhould≈øt rebuke mee in anger, I cannot endure it in affection, but I can le≈ø≈øe endure it in abilitie: It is grievous to mee, to thinke thou art angry, but it is in≈øupportable to mee, to feele thou art angry: the hand of thine anger is heavie, and though of thy ≈øelfe thou be as it were a ≈øweetly breathing ayre; yet anger maks thee a con≈øuming fire, that if thine anger be kindled, yea, but a little, Ble≈ø≈øed are all they that put their tru≈øt in thee.

When I con≈øider with my ≈øelfe the many favours, unde≈øerved favours, thou ha≈øt vouch≈øafed unto mee, and con≈øider withall, how little u≈øe, how ill u≈øe I have made of them all, though I know I have ju≈øtly de≈øerved thy rebuking, yet my hope is ≈øtill, thou wilt adde this favour al≈øo, not to rebuke me in thine anger: but when I thinke, how unkinde a thing thy rebuking is, but how terrible a thing thine anger is; when I thinke, what a paine it is to have thee cha≈øten mee, but what a death it is, to have thee cha≈øten mee in di≈øplea≈øure; then I fall a trembling in all my joynts, and never think I can make ha≈øte enough to ≈øay, and to ≈øay with ≈øighing; O Lord, rebuke mee not in thine anger, neither cha≈øten mee in thy heavie di≈øplea≈øure.

But why may not God rebuke mee, as Eli rebuked his ≈øonnes? for hee rebuked his ≈øons for their ≈øinnes, and yet no anger appeared in him at all. O my ≈øoule, wilt thou make Eli a pattern for God? becau≈øe God is a loving Father, wilt thou therefore make him like Eli, too indulgent a father? Ely indeed rebuked his ≈øonnes with a rod, but hee made his rod of Ro≈øes and Violets: hee rebuked them for ≈øins of pre≈øumption, as if they had been but ≈øins of infirmity: hee rebuked them for ≈øinnes of wilfulne≈ø≈øe, as if they had beene but ≈øinnes of ignorance: and what was this, but in≈øtead of ≈øtriking them, to ≈øtroake them, and in≈øtead of ≈øtopping them in their race, to adde rather a
≈øpurre unto them? And was it not for this, that God rebuked Eli in his anger, becau≈øe Eli rebuked not his ≈øonnes in his anger? I deny not O God, but that my ≈øinnes de≈øerve thine anger; or rather I acknowledge they ju≈øtly provoke thine anger: but alas, O Lord, if thou ≈øhoulde≈øt enter into judgement with thy ≈øervants, what fle≈øh were able to ≈øtand before thee, and not bee con≈øumed? O vile ≈øinne of mine, enough to put patience it ≈øelfe into choler, able to anger a ≈øaint, nay, even the King of ≈øaints. That if thou O God, ≈øhoulde≈øt rebuke mee in thine anger, if cha≈øten mee in thy heavie di≈øplea≈øure, I could not ≈øay, but that thine anger were lenitie, and thy di≈øplea≈øure, mildne≈ø≈øe.

But what boldne≈ø≈øe of language is this in ≈øpeaking to God? am I not worthy of rebuke, for praying God, not to rebuke mee in his anger, as though I thought that God could bee angry? For, is not anger a pa≈ø≈øion of humane infirmitie, and will I make God ≈øubject to pa≈ø≈øions of infirmitie? Is not anger a defect in rea≈øon is? not God a perfection above rea≈øon? and can there bee defect in perfection? can there bee pa≈ø≈øion in him, that is Purus Actus? But is it not, that anger in God is not a pa≈ø≈øion, but an action, not a defect, but an effect: for then is God ≈øayd to bee angry, when he puts his judgements in execution, when his rebukings tend not to conver≈øion, but to confu≈øion: when his mercy attempers not the rigour
of his ju≈øtice. Oh then, rebuke mee O God, but not in thine anger; rebuke me as thou did≈øt the Ninevites, who at thy rebuking repented and were converted: but rebuke mee not as thou did≈øt Pharaoh, who hardned his heart at thy rebuking, and was confounded. If thou O God, ≈øhould≈øt rebuke mee in thine anger, I ≈øhould more have an eye to thy rod, then give an eare to thy le≈ø≈øon: I ≈øhould bee more terrified with thine anger, then edified with thy rebuking, and ≈øhould be made uncapable of thy doctrine, with the terror of thy teaching: for I, alas, am as a nayle under the workmans hammer, better driven in with gentle ≈øtroakes, then with hard blowes: Oh therfore, rebuke mee not O God, if thou be angry, or if thou rebuke mee, bee not angry: Two ≈øuch ≈øharp notes, as anger and rebuking are, can never make any plea≈øing mu≈øicke, if they meet together. Anger in rebuking, makes the water troubled, and thick that ≈øhould be drunk cleere, makes the Ayre ≈øultry, and hot, that ≈øhould be breathed in cold, extremely both of them unwhole≈øome for the body: and ≈øeeing thou intende≈øt my health, and ≈øeeke≈øt not to make mee ≈øicke, Let not anger enflame thy rebuking O God, that ≈øo the ayre of it I may take in the cooler, that ≈øo the water of it I may drink the cleerer. I, alas, am as a narrow mouthed ve≈ø≈øell in the hand of the drawer, better filled with ≈øoftly pouring in, then with pouring in ha≈øtily, which commonly ≈øpills more then
it fills: and ≈øeeing thy rebuking is too precious a liquor to bee ≈øpilt, O poure it in with the ≈øoftly hand of patience, and not with the ha≈øtie hand of anger; that ≈øo it may the ≈øooner fil, & the better enter without ≈øpilling, into this narrow mouthed ve≈ø≈øell of my emptie ≈øoule. Thy rebuking O God, is to mee as thunder, but thine anger is as lightning: and is it not enough, that thou terrifie my ≈øoule with the thunder of thy rebuking, but thou wilt al≈øo ≈øet this flaxe of my fle≈øh on fire with the lightning of thine anger? Thy rebuking of it ≈øelfe is a precious Balme, but mixt with anger, turns to a Corro≈øive: O keepe thy Corro≈øives, O God, for ≈øuch hardned hearts as Pharaohs was; Apply to mee onely the ≈øimple Balme of thy rebuking, and let it not have any mixture at all of thy Corroding anger in it. What though I have offended thee with ≈øins of anger, mu≈øt thou needs take revenge, in the ≈øame kind thou art offended? and if needs thou mu≈øt doe ≈øo, why mai≈øt thou not then take revenge of my ≈øinnes in thy good plea≈øure, ≈øeeing I have offended thee as much with ≈øinnes of plea≈øure? Thou did≈øt walke in Paradi≈øe with our fir≈øt Parents, in the coole of the day, when the heate of the ≈øunne was over, and this made thy pre≈øence as cheerfull, as glorious: Vouch≈øafe O God, to deale ≈øo with mee, rebuke mee in the coole of thy Spirit, when the heat of thine anger is over-pa≈øt; for el≈øe alas, it may be glorious, but can never be comfortable.

But if rebuking me in thine anger, be ≈øo bitter a Potion, what is it then, to cha≈øten mee in thine indignation? for where the wor≈øt of thy rebuking in anger, is but threatning of puni≈øhment: the be≈øt of thy cha≈øtening in indignatioÃÑ, is inflicting of puni≈øhment: and though a ≈øtrong heart may perhaps endure ≈øuch threatnings, yet no ≈øtrength of heart is able to beare ≈øuch inflictings. It is terror enough to heare thee but chide, but to feele thee ≈øtrike, and that with ≈øtroakes of indignation, what power of any creature is able to endure it? I aske not, thou would≈øt not cha≈øten mee: this were to aske, thou would≈øt not love mee; for whom thou love≈øt, thou cha≈øtene≈øt; and would I lo≈øe thy love, for any cha≈øtening? O gracious God, cha≈øten mee in what manner, with what mea≈øure thou plea≈øe≈øt: cha≈øten mee as thou did≈øt Lazarus, by making him lye for hunger at Dives gate: cha≈øten me as thou did≈øt Iob, by making him lye with ≈øores upon the dunghill: cha≈øten mee, as thou did≈øt Daniel, by making him bee ca≈øt into the Lions denne: but then cha≈øten me in love, and not in indignation; for thy cha≈øtening in love, though it paine, yet it heales; though it brui≈øe, yet it comforts: Thy rod & thy ≈øtaff, they comfort me; but thy cha≈øtening in indignation, is paine without hope, is brui≈øing in de≈øpaire, or rather not a paine but a torment, not a brui≈øing, but a breaking: that no mi≈øery can bee comparable to this cha≈øtening, to be cha≈øtened in thine indignation.

Cha≈øtening and love may well bee matcht together, they are like to Iacob and Rachel, though there be ≈øeven yeares of ≈øervice more, yet Rachel will bee had at la≈øt: but cha≈øtening and indignation are as badly matcht as may bee, for cha≈øtening enclines to conver≈øion, and indignation is wholy bent upon confu≈øion; oh therefore, match thy cha≈øtening with love, and not with indignation, that ≈øo, at lea≈øt, I may come at la≈øt, to enjoy my Rachel, that is, thy favour: Cha≈øtening and love, may lodge both together in the bowels of a father, but indignation comes not where bowels are: and how then, O God, can≈øt thou cha≈øten me in indignation, but thou mu≈øt as it were disbowell thy ≈øelfe, and utterly abandon the name of a Father? and ≈øhall any thing make thee to leave that Name? I know, O God, it is a name ≈øo deare unto thee, that I hope I ≈øhall commit no ≈øuch ≈øinne; and ≈øuffer mee not O God, to commit any ≈øuch ≈øinne as ≈øhall ever be able to make thee abandon it. Indeed here, where wee call thee Lord, indignation may appeare, and bee bold to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe: but when wee come to name thee Father, indignation mu≈øt be gone, and never pre≈øume to come in place. If thy cha≈øtening bee intended for reforming, or for poli≈øhing, what would≈øt thou doe with indignation, that tends to aboli≈øhing? And if thou cha≈øten whom thou love≈øt, and then de≈øtroy whom thou cha≈øtene≈øt; what difference will there bee betweene thy indignation, and thy

Oh let not thy cha≈øtening, which is ordained to be a rod for thy children, be made a knife to ≈ølaughter thy Children: Con≈øider, O God, I am but a pot made of brittle Clay, that if thy hand hold not a temper in ≈øtriking, I ≈øhall ≈øoone bee broken, and beaten in pieces, and then thy workman≈øhip will bee defaced. Alas, my ≈øoule, I know full well, it were a grievous ca≈øe for mee, if God ≈øhould let his cha≈øtening and his indignation joyne together, and a≈ø≈øayle mee with them both at once; but how ≈øhall I doe to keepe them a≈øunder? Have I any Mo≈øes to ≈øtand for mee in the gap? Ble≈ø≈øed be thy glorious Name, O God: I have indeed a greater then Mo≈øes, even him, whom thou did≈øt cha≈øten in thy heavie di≈øplea≈øure; to the end thou might≈øt not cha≈øten mee in thy heavie di≈øplea≈øure; for his agonie of crying, My God, My God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken mee; gives mee boldne≈ø≈øe to cry, and confidence in crying, My God, My God, have mercy upon mee: This I know will helpe, when all other helps ≈øayle. But what have I in my ≈øelfe to plead, why God ≈øhould not cha≈øten mee in his heavie di≈øplea≈øure? Can I ≈øay,
I have not de≈øerved it? Or can I ≈øay I have not even provoked him to doe it? Alas, O God, I have nothing in thee to flie to, but onely thy mercy; nothing in my ≈øelfe to plead, but onely my weakne≈ø≈øe; Have mercy upon mee, O God, Ver≈øe 2 for I am weake.

But is not this a weak Plea, to alleage weakne≈ø≈øe for a Plea? weak indeed with men, who commonly tread harde≈øt upon the weake≈øt, and are ever going over where the hedge is lowe≈øt; but no weake Plea with God, who≈øe mercy is ever readie upon all occa≈øions, and then mo≈øt, when there is mo≈øt need: and ≈øeeing there is greate≈øt need, where there is greate≈øt weakne≈ø≈øe, therefore no Plea with God ≈øo ≈øtrong as this; Have mercy upon me, O God, for I am weake.

But why ≈øhould David pray for mercy to helpe his weakne≈ø≈øe? for what can mercy do? Mercy can but pitty his weaknes, it is ≈øtrength that mu≈øt relieve it. But is it not, that mercy, I may ≈øay, is as the ≈øteward of Gods hou≈øe, and hath the command of all he hath: that if wi≈øedome be wanting for direction, mercy can procure it. Let thy indignation, O God, be layd upon Pharaoh, and ≈øuch as tru≈øt in their ≈øtrength, for upon them thou mai≈øt get thee honour: but alas, what honour can bee gotten, by pouring thy indignation upon ≈øo weake a Creature as I am? O then bee plea≈øed in thy plenteous redemption, to grant mee this conjunction of deliverance and ≈øalvation, that I may returne thee the conjunction of prai≈øe and thank≈øgiving; and may ≈øing and ≈øay, O Lord, I will prai≈øe thee: though thou wa≈øt angry with mee, yet thine anger is turned away. Behold, God is my ≈øalvation, I will cru≈øt, and not bee afraid.

But how can God returne to deliver mee, and to ≈øave mee: if hee returne not a deliverer
and a ≈øaviour? and when will this bee? O my ≈øoule, in how much better ≈øtate art thou, then David was? for hee onely expected when it ≈øhould bee, but thou art a≈ø≈øured when it was. For then was God manife≈øted to returne a deliverer, and a Saviour, when the Angell brought this tidings to the ≈øhepherds; This day is borne to you a Saviour, of whom al≈øo a voice from heaven te≈øtified; This is my welbeloved Sonne, in whom I am well plea≈øed. Oh then return to me, in this Saviour, in whom, thou art well plea≈øed: that ≈øo I may bee ≈øure, for ≈øo I ≈øhall bee ≈øure thou wilt not cha≈øten me in thy di≈øplea≈øure.

As there have beene many particular Deluges and flouds, yet but one generall: ≈øo there have beene many particular deliverers and ≈øaviours, yet but one generall: and from this generall Saviour it is that I de≈øire & expect ≈øalvation: for though his being a generall Saviour, may make him bee thought le≈ø≈øe carefull of mee, having ≈øo many others to care for be≈øides: yet have no feare of that, my ≈øoule, ≈øeeing hee is as much a Saviour to mee, as if he were a Saviour to none but mee; and this generall Saviour will ≈øave mee generally, not only from temporall, but from ≈øpirituall enemies: Not onely from trouble of bones, but from trouble of ≈øoule: Not onely from mi≈øeries here on earth, but even from mi≈øeries, when earth it ≈øelfe ≈øhall bee no more. O happy ≈øalvation, when this Saviour ≈øhall come and ≈øave
mee: but how may I doe to get him to come? for hee comes not but upon ≈øome motive. If I had all the gold of Ophir, I would willingly give it all, to get him to come and ≈øave mee: but, alas, I neither have it to give, nor doth he care to have it: if any thing winne him to doe it, it mu≈øt bee for his mercies ≈øake, and for his mercies ≈øake hee will doe it, if ever hee will doe it.

But is not this ≈øtrange? My weakne≈ø≈øe was the motive before to move God to mercy; and mu≈øt his mercie now be it ≈øelfe the motive to move him to ≈øave mee? yet ≈øo it is: For when Gods mercie findes no motive from us; rather then fayle of moving, it becomes a motive to it ≈øelfe: and happy it is from us, that ≈øo it is: for el≈øe we might often be without it, when mo≈øt wee need it: or rather alwaies bee without it, ≈øeeing wee alwaies need it. Indeed this motive, For his mercies ≈øake, is the Primum mobile of all motives to God, for ≈øhewing his favour. Hee had never delivered the I≈øraelites out of Egypt, but for his mercies ≈øake: Hee had never ≈øaved Noah in the Arke, but for his mercies ≈øake: but above all, Hee had never ≈øent his Sonne to ≈øave the world, but for his mercies ≈øake: And how then can I doubt, and not rather be confident, that for his mercies ≈øake hee will al≈øo deliver my ≈øoule, and ≈øave mee. Never therefore my ≈øoule looke after any further motives: for upon this motive will I ≈øet up my re≈øt: His mercie ≈øhall be both my
Anchor, and my harbour; it ≈øhall bee both my Armour, and my Fortre≈ø≈øe: it ≈øhall be both my ran≈øome and my garland; it ≈øhall bee both my deliverance and my ≈øalvation.

And now, O God, thou ≈øee≈øt the manifold troubles I am in, thou ≈øee≈øt how weake I am; thou ≈øee≈øt how my bones are troubled; thou ≈øee≈øt how my ≈øoule is troubled; and what now can thy cha≈øtening hand have more of me, but onely to take away my life? and even my life I would willingly make a ≈øacrifice to appea≈øe thy di≈øplea≈øure. Ver≈øe 5 But alas, O Lord, what good can it bee to thee, to have mee die? Can I prai≈øe thee in the du≈øt? but can I prai≈øe thee when I am turned to du≈øt? Is there remembrance of thee in death? or is there hallowing of thy Name in the grave? As long as I have breath in my bodie, I can prai≈øe thy Name: unworthily indeed, but yet I can prai≈øe it: As long as I am numbred among the living, I can ≈øhew my ≈øelfe thy ≈øervant; an unprofitable one indeed, but yet a ≈øervant: but if my ≈øoule and bodie bee di≈ø≈øolved once, alas, then all my ≈øervice of pray≈øing thee is at an end, I cannot then doe it, though I would; but I cannot then will it, though I ≈øhould: my ≈øoule will want her in≈øtruments with which thy prai≈øes ≈øhould be ≈øounded. O vile death, I hate thee for nothing ≈øo much, as for thy hindring mee in this ≈øervice? O cruell grave, I abhorre thee ≈øo much for nothing, as for thy ≈øtopping my mouth for this pray≈øing? O mercifull God,
If I could but remember thee in death, I would never bee loath to die. If I could but prai≈øe thee in the grave, I would willingly goe to it of my ≈øelfe, and never bee carried to it by force: but alas, death is forgetfull, the grave is dumbe; and therefore deliver my ≈øoule, O God, ≈øave mee for thy mercies ≈øake.

It is not life that is ≈øo deare unto mee: but that in life I may prai≈øe thee, that art ≈øo deare unto mee: It is not death that is ≈øo frightfull to mee, but this affrights mee in death, that being dead, I cannot remember thee: It is not the grave that is ≈øo loath≈øome to mee, but that in the grave I am forced to forget thee; If death will ≈øpare me but to prai≈øe thee, let death come and never ≈øpare mee: If the grave will but let mee bee ≈øen≈øible of thee, the grave ≈øhall come and bee welcome to me; but alas, death hath no mercie, the grave hath no ≈øen≈øe: and therfore return, O Lord, and deliver my ≈øoule, ≈øave mee for thy mercies ≈øake.

Who knowes not, that death is a mortall enemie to all naturall memory: and therefore makes all men at la≈øt to end in a Lethargie: and what hope then of remembring thee in death? Who knows not that the grave never opens its mouth to let out any thing, but ≈øtill to take in? and what meanes then of prai≈øing thee in the grave. If I could but get death to learne the Art of memory, or if I could but heare the grave to ≈øay once it had enough; I could then like to have ≈øome dealing with death, ≈øome
traffique with the grave but alas, deaths Lethargie is incurable, the graves mouth is in≈øatiable; and therefore returne, O Lord, and deliver my ≈øoule, ≈øave mee for thy mercies ≈øake.

But doth Davids prayer tend to this, that hee may not ≈øee death? is this the intent of his reque≈øt, that hee may not de≈øcend into the pit? doth hee pray to bee as Enoch, or Elias, taken from the earth, without returning into earth? Alas, hee knowes this to bee either altogether impo≈ø≈øible, or altogether unlikely: and therfore no likely reque≈øt to bee made by ≈øo wi≈øe a man. This therefore is certainely the intent of his prayer, that God will not ≈øo cha≈øten him in his indignation, as to leave him in the hands of death: but that as death receives him from life, and delivers him to the grave, ≈øo the grave receiving him from death, may deliver him againe to life, that as Chri≈øt commanded his Apo≈øtles to ≈øhake off the du≈øt from their feet, when they came into any unworthy hou≈øe, and to come away; ≈øo hee comming into this unworthy hou≈øe of death, the dungeon of the grave, may bee able to ≈øhake off the du≈øt from his feet, and by the power of of him that ≈øaid, Lazarus come forth, have his ≈øoule and bodie reunited againe: and ≈øo united, bee admitted into the quire of Saints and Angels, eternally to ≈øing the eternall Allelujah. For as the departing of the ≈øoule from the bodie, is the death of the bodie; ≈øo
the dividing of the bodie from the ≈øoule, is a kinde of death to the ≈øouler that it is not, as it would bee, nor fully enjoyes it ≈øelfe, untill it can meete with the bodie, and bee united to it againe: For though it find the bodie here but a ba≈øe cottage, or rather a loath≈øome pri≈øon, yet it ≈øhall finde it there a glorious Palace, or rather a holy Temple con≈øecrated to God: and therefore untill this bee had, it will not fully be accompli≈øhed that is here prayed for: Returne, O God, and deliver my ≈øoule, ≈øave mee, for thy mercies ≈øake.

The remembrance of this, that I cannot rememember thee in death, makes mee forgetfull of my ≈øelfe in life: and becau≈øe I cannot prai≈øe thee, nor pray to thee in the grave, it makes me to ≈øigh and weepe to thee in my bed: and what I want in continuance, to ≈øupply with violence. Ver≈øe 6 For I am weary with my ≈øighing: all the night make I my bed to ≈øwimme, I water my cowch with my teares. Oh let my remembring thee in life, ≈øupply the place of my forgetting thee in death: and when I lye in my grave ≈øen≈øle≈ø≈øe and ≈øilent, bee plea≈øed to remember how I have lyen in my bed ≈øighing and weeping. My ≈øinnes, as being di≈øordinate pa≈ø≈øions, make me undergo a pa≈ø≈øive pennance: and this hath beene my weakne≈ø≈øe, my trouble of bones, and my trouble of ≈øoule: but being al≈øo di≈øordinate actions, they make mee liable al≈øo to doe active pennance: and what is this, but my ≈øighing, and my weeping? and though
I cannot act ≈øorrow, ≈øo well as ≈øinne, yet my bed and my couch can be witne≈ø≈øes of my ≈øorrow, as well as of my ≈øinne. Mine eyes indeed chiefly have done the pennance, becau≈øe mine eyes fir≈øt began the offence: if mine eyes had not ≈øet mee fir≈øt on fire, mine eyes had not ≈øhed ≈øuch ≈øhowers of teares: but now, how could burning bee quenched but with water? how burning ri≈øing from mine eyes; but with water falling from mine eyes? But yet why ≈øhould my bed ≈øuffer? for my bed had no hand in the fault of mine eyes? but alas, how could my bed but prove a Deodand; which ≈øo apparently, I may ≈øay, did Movere ad mortem? Though my bed were not principall in the act, yet my bed was acce≈ø≈øary to the fact, as receiving unlawfull and ≈øtollen plea≈øures.

But though my ≈øinnes indeed bee my greate≈øt enemies, yet there are per≈øonall enemies that have their malignity al≈øo, which though I cannot ≈øay they trouble mee as ill, yet I may truely ≈øay, they trouble mee as well as the≈øe: for mine eye is con≈øumed becau≈øe of griefe, Ver≈øe 7 and is waxen old, becau≈øe of all mine enemies. You may ≈øay perhaps that my ≈øighes were feigned, and that my teares were counterfeit: but the con≈øumption of mine eye, is a witne≈ø≈øe of my ≈øorrow, without exception; that if my pa≈ø≈øive pennance before, were not cau≈øe ≈øufficient: at lea≈øt, my active pennance now gives mee ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øay, Was ever ≈øorrow like my ≈øorrow? was ever griefe like this of mine?
And all this pennance I ≈øuffer and doe, becau≈øe of mine enemies: for how could I chu≈øe but ≈øigh and weepe, to ≈øee the vile, the execrable dealing of mine enemies, that per≈øecute me in their hearts, and yet ≈øpeake peace with their mouthes: that lay ≈øhares to entrap mee, and yet beare mee in hand it ≈øhall be for my good: that prejudice my cau≈øe, as if it would never ≈øucceed; and prejudicate my prayers, as if they would never bee heard.

But what meanes David by this? will not his weeping make his enemies rejoyce the more? will not the ≈øeeing him thus dejected, make them the more in≈øulting over him? will they not bee readie to ≈øay, Is this hee that encountered a Lion, and a Beare? Hee that entred combate with a Giant, the terrour of a whole Armie; and now to fall a crying one cannot tell for what? But David is a better husband of his teares then to ≈øpend them idly, hee knowes for what hee ≈øpends them, becau≈øe of his enemies indeed, but not for feare of his enemies: They are neither teares of feare; for whom ≈øhould hee feare, that hath God on his ≈øide? Nor teares of vaine glory; for why then ≈øhould hee ≈øhed them in the night, when none can ≈øee them: Nor teares of joy; for how then ≈øhould they make him looke old, which is an effect of griefe: but they are tears of ≈øupplication, and teares of compa≈ø≈øion. Fir≈øt of ≈øupplication; that God will either convert them, or confound them: and not converting,
then teares of compa≈ø≈øion, to thinke of their confu≈øion. For ≈øuch is the tenderne≈ø≈øe of a godly eye, that it hath teares to ≈øhed even for enemies: And when the≈øe two waters, the teares of ≈øupplication, and the teares of compa≈ø≈øion meet together, what mervaile if they make a floud in Davids bed, ≈øeeing the concour≈øe of like waters made the great Deluge in the whole world? for what are his teares of ≈øupplication, but as the waters that ro≈øe from the ≈øprings of the earth? and what are his teares of compa≈ø≈øion, but as the waters that fell from the Cataracts of heaven? Or is it not perhaps that David makes his enemies here, a figure of his ≈øinnes, which are indeed his greate≈øt enemies? as al≈øo that hee makes his owne pa≈ø≈øion, a figure of Chri≈øts compa≈ø≈øion, which was indeed one of his pa≈ø≈øions? for then hee wept over Ieru≈øalem in compa≈ø≈øion of their confu≈øion, when with teares of ≈øupplication hee could not prevaile with them, in compa≈ø≈øing their conver≈øion: when they would not heare him how often hee would have gathered them together as a Hen gathereth her Chickens, with teares of ≈øupplication, Then they heare him ≈øay, There ≈øhall not a ≈øtone be left upon another, which ≈øhall not be ca≈øt down, with teares of compa≈ø≈øion.

I grieve not ≈øo much that mine eye is waxen old, though it bee waxen old with griefe, as I grieve to ≈øee that my enemies have no eyes at all, at lea≈øt, no eyes but of malice, who rejoyce
at my afflictions, and make them≈øelves as merry with my weeping eyes, as the Phili≈øtims made them≈øelves with Samp≈øons blinded eyes. I grieve to ≈øee their de≈øtruction draw neere, and they laugh at my grieving, and at the oldne≈ø≈øe, and alteration which griefe hath brought upon mee. And was it not ≈øo with my Saviour Chri≈øt, which made the Iewes ≈øay; thou art not yet fifty yeares old, as though he looked like one neere fifty, when hee was indeed not much above thirty:

But ≈øeeing with all my ≈øighing and grieving, I cannot reclaim them; I here di≈øclaime them: Ver≈øe 8 Depart from mee, all ye workers of iniquitie: Away from mee, all yee that are Wolves in ≈øheepes cloathing: I put not away poore penitent ≈øinners, that do pennance for their ≈øins as I have done, and may rather bee ≈øaid to ≈øuffer ≈øinne, then to doe it; as being more of infirmity, then of will: I put away them that make iniquitie their work, and thinke it a pennance when they bee not committing of ≈øinne: Them that are journeymen to the trade, or rather Ma≈øters in the my≈øterie, Them that vilifie my ≈øighes, and ≈øay, they are but ≈øutors In forma pauperis, and therefore that God ≈øcornes them that reproach my teares, and ≈øay, they are but dumbe ≈øolicitors, and therefore God cannot heare them: but ≈øee how much they are deceived: For now contrary to their hopes, and more to their wi≈øhes; The Lord hath heard the voice of my teares, hath heard it:
and therfore does not ≈øcorn it; the voice of my teares, and therefore my teares are not dumbe: and where all other voices may bee doubted, whether God will heare them or no: the voice of teares, hath Gods eare, I may ≈øay, at command; at lea≈øt is never denied acce≈ø≈øe unto his hearing. And this is but my fir≈øt, and lowe≈øt degree of comfort, for a higher then this: Ver≈øe 9 Hee hath heard my reque≈øt. But what? hath God no Ma≈øters of Reque≈øt about him, but is Ma≈øter of Reque≈øts him≈øelfe? Indeed when hee would know the ≈øinnes of Sodome, hee tooke not information from the Angels, but came downe him≈øelfe to ≈øee: and ≈øhould he in per≈øon ≈øee ≈øinnes, and not in per≈øon heare prayers? And to ≈øhew him≈øelfe to be his own Ma≈øter of reque≈øts indeed, he hath taken my petition into his hands; that I cannot now doubt of having my reque≈øt granted: ≈øeeing the Prince that mu≈øt grant it, is him≈øelfe the Ma≈øter of Reque≈øts to pre≈øent it: and what is it to receive a ≈øupplication into his hands, but to receive the ≈øuppliant into his favour?

If hee onely heard the voice of my teares; I might doubt le≈øt he thought them but like the teares of E≈øau, and ≈øo ≈øhould ≈ølight them: Or if hee onely heard my reque≈øt, I might feare le≈øt he thought it but like the reque≈øt of the mother of Zebedees ≈øonnes, and ≈øo reject it: but now that hee hath taken my ≈øupplication into his hands, now I may bee ≈øure hee meanes to doe ≈øomething in it: ≈øeeing hee never takes
any thing in hand, which hee brings not to a happy and ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull period, again≈øt all oppo≈øition. The voice of my tears brought God to ca≈øt his eye upon mee: My reque≈øt brought him to bow his eare unto mee: but the taking my ≈øupplication into his hand, hath brought him to compa≈ø≈øionate my e≈øtate: and ≈øeeing his compa≈ø≈øion is active, and his pitty relieving; my teares of ≈øorrow may now bee turned into teares of joy, my lamentations into ≈øongs of thanks giving. The lamentable accent of my language, made God fir≈øt to looke upon mee: The pittifull nature of my ≈øuite, made him next to li≈øten to mee: but the ju≈øtne≈ø≈øe of my cau≈øe in hand, made him la≈øtly, to take my petion into his hand, which is in effect to grant it out of hand.

Indeed God is with no mu≈øicke ≈øo much delighted, as with that of voyces; with no voyces ≈øo much, as with tho≈øe of teares; with no teares ≈øo much, as with tho≈øe of the heart, and ≈øuch were mine, though ≈øent forth by the eies: And now, who≈øe eyes would not be moved at ≈øo ≈øtrange a ≈øight, to heare eyes ≈øpeak? who≈øe eares would not be moved at ≈øo ≈øtrange a hearing, to ≈øee tears bee a ≈øutour? who≈øe hands would refu≈øe ≈øo ≈øtrange a writing, where eies, I may ≈øay, are the Penne, teares the Inke, and ≈øighes the paper? Pardon my curio≈øity O God, in imagining wonders, while I meditate of thee, in whom are nothing but wonders.

And what remaines now, but that my ≈øorrowes
remove their lodging, and ≈øojourn with my enemies, as they have done with me: what remaines, but that my ≈øighes bee turned upon mine enemies brea≈øts, my teares upon their eyes, and that the pit they digged for me, they may fall into them≈øelves; and that, with the violence of falling ≈øuddenly. As for me, I ≈øhall live to ≈øee mine enemies turne their backs and be a≈øhamed: I ≈øhall live to ≈øee them hide their faces, and be confounded: but before all, and above all, I ≈øhall live to magnifie thy glorious Name, O God, who art ble≈ø≈øed for ever.

But is Davids charity come to this, to bee turned into cur≈øings and imprecations? Indeed no otherwi≈øe then God to the Serpent, when hee ≈øayd, Cur≈øed art thou above all Cattell: for when men are growne into that reprobate ≈øen≈øe, that they are more like to limbes of Sathan, then to creatures after the Image of God; then it is lawfull in Gods cau≈øe, to take Gods cour≈øe, and to turne them over to ≈øhame and confu≈øion. *‚Åé*

div.p: BLe≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe was cried in the fir≈øt P≈øalme, but was there held ≈øo deare, that few or none have ever been able to go to the price. Now in this P≈øalme it is cried againe, and at a low rate; and if it bee not taken now, it is not like hereafter to bee ever had ≈øo cheape again. For, where before it mu≈øt have co≈øt an ab≈øolute declining from ≈øin, and a perfect delighting in the Law of God, with a continuall exerci≈øing in it day and night; Now if wee can but get our iniquities to bee remitted, and our ≈øinnes to bee covered, it will ≈øerve the turne, and bee accepted.

But is this ≈øo much an ea≈øier rate? For though the purcha≈øing of Ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe, were before a great worke to bee done, yet it was a worke that might bee done by our ≈øelves: where the purcha≈øing it this way, mu≈øt be the worke of another: and were it not better to have it by a way in our owne power, then by
a way in anothers will? But O my ≈øoule, Is it in man to direct his own way? Is it in mans power, to performe the worke that is required? hath hee not long ≈øince put out the light that ≈øhould have guided him in it? hath hee not long ago cut off the lock, that ≈øhould have beene his ≈øtrength to performe it? Oh therefore, ble≈ø≈øed bee hee that affords us ble≈ø≈øednes at this rate: For though it bee in anothers will to grant it, yet con≈øider who≈øe will it is; even his that is more readie to forgive, then we are readie to aske forgivene≈ø≈øe, and is rather a ≈øuitour to us to take a pardon, then ≈øtayes for us to bee ≈øuitours to have a pardon.

div.head: MEDITATIONS upon the 38. P≈øalme.
div.p:
BUt is it not an ab≈øurd reque≈øt, Ver≈øe 1 to require God, not to rebuke mee in his anger; as though I thought hee would rebuke mee if hee were not angry? Is it not a ≈øen≈øle≈ø≈øe ≈øuite, to pray to God, not to cha≈øten mee in his di≈øplea≈øure; as though hee would cha≈øten mee if hee were not di≈øplea≈øed? The frowarde≈øt natures that
are, will yet be quiet as long as they be plea≈ø'd: and ≈øhall I have ≈øuch a thought, of the great, yet gracious God, that hee ≈øhould be plea≈ø'd, and yet not bee quiet? But O my ≈øoule, Is it all one, to rebuke in his anger, and to rebuke when hee is angry? He may rebuke when hee is angry, and yet re≈øtraine and bridle in his anger: but to rebuke in his anger, is to let loo≈øe the reines to his anger: and what is it to give the reines to his anger, but to make it out-run his mercy? and then what a mi≈øerable ca≈øe ≈øhould I bee in, to have his anger to a≈ø≈øault me, and not his mercie readie to relieve mee? to have his in dignation fall upon mee, when his loving kindne≈ø≈øe were not by to take it off? Oh therefore, rebuke mee not in thine anger, O God: but let thy rebuking ≈øtay for thy mercie; cha≈øten mee not in thy di≈øplea≈øure, but let thy lovingkindne≈ø≈øe have the keeping of thy rod.

But though the reque≈øt be never ≈øo ju≈øt; yet mu≈øt it not needs be a weari≈øome thing to God, to have us alwaies come to him with the ≈øame petition, as though wee would per≈øecute him with importunity, and make him doe that, which he is not willing to doe? for if he were willing to grant it, hee would no doubt have done it before now; when in the ≈øixth P≈øalme, we asked him as earne≈øtly for it, as we can doe in this. But O my ≈øoule, is importunity a fault? if it bee, it is a fault I ≈øhall hardly bee per≈øwaded ever to leave. Did Chri≈øt
count it a fault in the woman of Canaan, who would take no an≈øwer; but ≈øtill cried after him, till hee granted her ≈øuite? Did not Abraham importune God five times, about the ≈øparing of Sodome? and did not God grant as long as hee importun'd? And may wee not thinke that if hee had continued his importunity ≈øtill, hee might as well have gotten Sodome to bee ≈øpared for one mans ≈øake, as hee had done for ten? Is God like man, that the importunitie of ≈øuitours ≈øhould bee a trouble to him? Can wee thinke, that God ≈øhould bee di≈øplea≈øed with our importunity to him, when he is plea≈øed to u≈øe importunity him≈øelfe to us? Did not God call to Samnel, three times one after another; when hee bid him go to Eli, with a me≈ø≈øage? Was it not importunity which Chri≈øt u≈øed to Peter, when thrice together hee asked him, Simon ≈øonne of Ionas, love≈øt thou mee? Indeed Peter ≈øeemed not well plea≈ø'd with this importunity: but God never was, never will bee found to bee di≈øplea≈øed with it. Never therefore feare to bee importunatewith God; but feare rather, thou can≈øt never bee importunate enough; for ≈øo highly is God plea≈øed, or rather indeed delighted with our importunity in praying, that hee oftentimes denies the fir≈øt ≈øuit of his ≈øervants, becau≈øe he would bee importun'd by a ≈øecond; oftentimes the ≈øecond, becau≈øe hee would have a third. Indeed, that which in ≈øuits to men is importunitie, in ≈øuits to God is fervencie and per≈øeverance,
and ≈øeemes to re≈øemble the nature of the Seraphims; where ≈øingle prayer but of ordinary Angels, of whom as ≈øome fell, ≈øo this may faile, and often doth, the other never.

But though importunity bee to God mo≈øt plea≈øing alwaies: yet to us, it is then mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, when the cheerfull face of God is turned into frownes: and when there is a ju≈øtly conceived feare of the continuance of his anger: and have not I ju≈øt cau≈øe to feare it, having the arrowes of his anger ≈øticking ≈øo fa≈øt in mee? if hee had meant to make me but a Butt, at which to ≈øhoot his arrows; he would quickly, I ≈øuppo≈øe, have taken them up againe; but now that hee leaves them ≈øticking in mee, what can I think, but that he meanes to make mee his quiver; and then I may looke long enough, before hee come to plucke them out. They are arrows indeed that are fethered with ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe, and headed with ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe; and to give them a force in flying, they are ≈øhot, I may ≈øay, out of his Cro≈ø≈øe-bow, I am ≈øure his bow of cro≈ø≈øes: for no arrowes can flie ≈øo fa≈øt, none pierce ≈øo deep, as the cro≈ø≈øes & afflictions with which he hath ≈øurprized me: I may truly ≈øay ≈øurprized me; ≈øeeing when I thought my ≈øelf mo≈øt ≈øafe, and ≈øaid, I ≈øhall never be moved even then the≈øe arrows of his anger lighted upoÃÑ me, and ≈øtick ≈øo fa≈øt in my fle≈øh, that no arm but his that ≈øhot them, is ever able to draw them forth Oh then, as thou ha≈øt ≈øtretched forth thine arme of anger, O God, to ≈øhoot the≈øe arrowes
at mee; So ≈øtretch forth thine arme of mercy, to draw them forth; that I may rather ≈øing Hymns, then Dyrges unto thee: and that thou mai≈øt ≈øhew thy power, as well in pardoning, as thou ha≈øt done in condemning. I, alas, am as an Anvile under two hammers: one, of thine anger, another of my ≈øinne; both of them beating ince≈ø≈øantly upon mee; the hammer of thine anger, beating upon my fle≈øh, and making that un≈øound: the hammer of my ≈øin, beating upon my bones, and making them unquiet; although indeed both beat upon both: but thine anger more upon my fle≈øh, as being more ≈øen≈øible: my ≈øin more upon my bones, as being more obdurate. Gods anger and ≈øin, are the two efficient cau≈øes of all mi≈øery; but the Procatarkticke cau≈øe indeed, is ≈øin: Gods anger, like the hou≈øe that Samp≈øon pulled upon his own head, falls not upon us, but when we pull it upon our ≈øelves, by ≈øinne.

I know by the un≈øoundne≈ø≈øe of my fle≈øh, that God is angry with me: for if it were not for his anger, my fle≈øh would bee ≈øound: but what ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe can be in it now, when Gods angry hand lies beating upon it continually, and never cea≈øeth? I know by the unquietnes of my bones, that I have ≈øinne in my bo≈øome; for if it were not for ≈øinne, my bones would bee quiet: But what quietne≈ø≈øe can bee in them now, when ≈øin lies gnawing upon them ince≈ø≈øantly, with the worme of remor≈øe? one would thinke my bones were farre enough removed,
and clo≈øely enough hidden from ≈øins doing them any hurt: yet ≈øee the ≈øearching nature, the venemous poy≈øon of ≈øinne, which pierceth through my fle≈øh, and makes unquietne≈ø≈øe in my very bones.

I know my fle≈øh is guilty of many faults, by which it ju≈øtly de≈øerves un≈øoundne≈ø≈øe: but what have my bones done? for they mini≈øter no fuell to the flames of my fle≈øhes ≈øen≈øuality; and why then ≈øhould they bee troubled? But are not my bones ≈øupporters of my fle≈øh, and are they not by this, at lea≈øt acce≈ø≈øary to my fle≈øhes faults? as acce≈ø≈øaries then, they are ≈øubject to the ≈øame puni≈øhment the fle≈øh it ≈øelfe is, which is the principall.

I cannot but wonder at this condition in my ≈øelfe: there is nothing I more loath then ≈øinne, yet nothing I more willingly embrace: nothing that I more abhorre, yet nothing I more readily entertaine: what mervaile then, if their bee un≈øoundne≈ø≈øe in my fle≈øh, and unquietne≈ø≈øe in my bones, when I will needes bee taking ≈øo turbulent a gue≈øt, ≈øo deadly a poy≈øon as ≈øinne is into my bo≈øome? and make an idoll of that, which I know ≈øo well to bee a mon≈øter?

As a man that ≈øtands in the water, as long as it comes but to his middle, or but up to his ≈øhoulders, endures and beares it ≈øafty enough; but when it comes once to goe over his head, it then overwhelmes and pre≈øently ≈øtrangles him: ≈øuch alas am I, my ≈øinne a long time,
came I may ≈øay, but up to my ≈øhoulders; and then I thought my ≈øelfe ≈øafe enough; now God knowes, I am over head and eares in ≈øinne, and ≈øo overwhelmed with it, that my breath is taken from mee, and I have not ≈øo much as any breath of Grace remaining in me. No ≈øtrength is ≈øo great, but it may be overburdened, though Samp≈øon went light away with the gates of Azzah; yet when a whole hou≈øe fell upon him, it cru≈øhed him to death. And ≈øuch, alas, am I, I have had ≈øin as a burden upon mee, ever ≈øince I was borne: but bore them a long time as light, as Samp≈øon did the gates of Azzah; but now that I have pulled a whole hou≈øe of ≈øinne upon mee, how can I chu≈øe but be cru≈øhed to death with ≈øo great a weight? And cru≈øhed, O my Soule, thou ≈øhould≈øt be indeed; if God for all his anger, did not take ≈øome pitty on thee: and for all his di≈øplea≈øure, did not ≈øtay his hand from further cha≈øtening thee.

I know, O Lord, I have done mo≈øt fooli≈øhly, to let my ≈øores runne ≈øo long, without ≈øeeking for helpe: For now, Ver≈øe 5 My wounds ≈øtinke and are corrupt; in as ill a ca≈øe as Lazarus body was, when it had beene foure daies buried; enough to make any man de≈øpaire, that did not know thee as I doe: For, doe not I know, that Nullum tempus occurrit tibi? doe not I know, thou ha≈øt as well wi≈øedome to remedy my fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe, as power to cure my wounds? Could the grave hold Lazarus, when thou did≈øt but open thy mouth to call him forth? No more
can the corruption of my ≈øores, bee any hinderance to their healing, when thy plea≈øure is to have them be cured. Although therfore I have done my owne di≈øcretion wrong to deferre my care; yet I will not doe thy power wrong, to de≈øpaire of thy cure: for, how ≈øhould I de≈øpair, who know thee to be as powerfull, as thou art mercifull; if I may not rather ≈øay, to bee as mercifull, as thou art powerfull: Each of them indeed an Aby≈ø≈øus: and when Aby≈ø≈øus Aby≈ø≈øum vocat, what marvell, if their follow marvells?

And as I do not de≈øpaire, ≈øo neither do I pre≈øume: Ver≈øe 6 For I am troubled, I am bowed downe, and go mourning all the day long. I am troubled no le≈ø≈øe with the griefe of thy di≈øplea≈øure, then with the paine of my wounds: each of them alone, ju≈øt cau≈øe of mourning; but both of them together, of mourning all the day long.

I have told hertofore, how I ≈øpend my night: all the night I water my bed with teares. Now I tell how I ≈øpend my day; all the day long in mourning. And can it be, O God, thou ≈øhould≈øt neither regard my weeping, nor my mourning? neither my weeping all night, nor my mourning all day?

If my fle≈øh had continued as God made it, there had been in it, both ≈øoundnes, and beautie; but alas, my ≈øinne, and his arrowes, his arrowes by rea≈øon of my ≈øin, have ≈øo wounded it, that it is nothing now, but a very Ci≈øtern of corruption: for all ≈øinne hath poy≈øon in it, and breedes di≈øea≈øes; infinite di≈øea≈øes in the Soule,
loath≈øome di≈øea≈øes in the bodie. And what will not di≈øea≈øes doe in the≈øe bodies of ours? who≈øe ≈øpirits can be ≈øo errect, but will bee dejected? who≈øe limbes ≈øo ≈øtrong, but will bee bowed downe? who≈øe heart ≈øo cheerefull, but will bee made to mourne with the violence of di≈øea≈øes? And now therfore, am I dejected, I am bowed down, I gomourning all the day long and may I not ≈øay, with the wor≈øt kinde of mourning, the mourning perhaps of the chyne: like Hor≈øe and Mule that have no under≈øtanding? For my loynes are filled with a loath≈øome di≈øea≈øe: the very di≈øea≈øe, that made Elias,
Ver≈øe 7 and Iohn Bapti≈øt to weare girdles of bea≈øts skins about their loynes; and they with wearing ≈øuch girdles, prevented in them≈øelves, the loath≈øomne≈ø≈øe of this di≈øea≈øe: but I, alas, never thought of any girdle, much le≈ø≈øe of Bea≈øts skins: and therefore the di≈øea≈øe is now grown ≈øo loath≈øome upon mee, that it hath filled my loynes; ≈øo filled them, that it hath not ≈øo much as a ≈øpare room left to make a perfume in; ≈øo loath≈øome, that it makes me fit for no company but Lazars, for no place but an Ho≈øpitall: for how ≈øhould others endure the ≈øtinch of my ≈øores, when I am not able to endure it my ≈øelfe? how much le≈ø≈øe, O God, can≈øt thou endure it, who≈øe pure ≈øen≈øe is ≈øen≈øible, even of that impurity, which is to us in≈øen≈øible, in the ≈øtarres them≈øelves? Thou, O God, did≈øt vouch≈øafe this favour to our fir≈øt Parents, to make them garments of Bea≈øts skins to cover their nakedne≈ø≈øe, and may wee
not be bold to think, that the Girdles of Bea≈øts skins, which Elias and Iohn Bapti≈øt wore about their loynes, were al≈øo of thy making? Oh then vouch≈øafe, O God, to give me ≈øuch a girdle to weare about my loynes; a girdle of continence & true mortification; which though it cannot now, as in Elias and Iohn Bapti≈øt it did, prevent the growth and loath≈øomne≈ø≈øe of concupi≈øcence in mee: It may at lea≈øt, as in Mary Magdalen re≈øtraine it, and make mee capable of being cured.

And as I have not de≈øpaired, Ver≈øe 8 nor pre≈øumed: ≈øo neither have I murmured nor repined at thy cha≈øti≈øements: I acknowledge my ≈øelfe mo≈øt worthy to ≈øuffer them, but mo≈øt unable to bear them. I am dejected no le≈ø≈øe in body, then in ≈øpirit; and yet though I could not ≈øpeake for weakne≈ø≈øe, I have roured for griefe; and the unquietnes of my heart, hath ≈øupplied the feeblenes of my tongue. Indeed if I could have been a Boanerges, and have gotten a voice like thunder, I ≈øhould have u≈øed it now in ≈øpeaking to thee; that if my importunity before could not, at lea≈øt my loudne≈ø≈øe now might prevaile with thee, to procure thee to hear me. For I am feeble and ≈øore broken, I have roared through the unquietnes of my heart. All long of the unquietnes of my heart, and the unquietnes of my heart, all long of my ≈øin: for where ≈øin is, there will never be but unquietnes of heart, & an unquiet heart will alwaies produce the≈øe mi≈øerable effects: Feeblenes of body, dejectedne≈ø≈øe of mind, and
roaring of voice.

But how can roaring ≈øtand with feeblene≈ø≈øe, which ≈øeemes to require a ≈øtrength of ≈øpirits? Is it not therefore a roaring, perhaps not ≈øo much in lowdne≈ø≈øe, as in an inarticulate expre≈ø≈øing? that having done actions more like a bea≈øt then a man, I am forced to u≈øe a voice, not ≈øo much of a man, as of a bea≈øt? Or is it perhaps a roaring in ≈øpirit, which the heart may ≈øend forth, though the bodie bee feeble: or rather then mo≈øt, when it is mo≈øt feeble: not unlike the blaze of a Candle, then greate≈øt, when going out. How≈øoever it be, this is certaine; the heart is that unhappy plot of ground which receiving into it the accur≈øed ≈øeed of ≈øinne, brings forth in the bodie and ≈øoule of man, the≈øe mi≈øerable fruits: and how then can I be free from the≈øe weedes of the fruits, that have received into me ≈øo great a mea≈øure of the ≈øeed? O vile ≈øinne, that I could as well avoid thee, as I can ≈øee thee; or could as ea≈øily re≈øi≈øt thee, as I deadly hate thee; I ≈øhould not then complaine of either feeblene≈ø≈øe of bodie, or dejectedne≈ø≈øe of mind, or roaring of voice: but I ≈øhould perfectly injoy that happie quietne≈ø≈øe in all my parts, which thou, O God, did≈øt graciou≈øly be≈øtow as a ble≈ø≈øed dowrie on our fir≈øt Parents, at their creation. And now, Ver≈øe 9 O my ≈øoule, let mee aske thee a que≈øtion: Why art thou ca≈øt downe, and why art thou di≈øquieted within mee? But what neede was thereof roaring? for what matter is it whether I ≈øpeake to God in a ≈øoft voice, or in a lowd? ≈øeeing thou knowe≈øt, O God, the very thoughts of my heart, and my groaning is not hid from thee. Though I ≈øpeake not, but onely thinke to ≈øpeake, yet thou knowe≈øt it: though I think not, but onely groane to think, yet thou knowe≈øt it; and knowing the≈øe things, thou knowe≈øt O God, that my griefe is more for thy di≈øplea≈øure, then for my wounds: le≈ø≈øe for the paine I feele of thine arrowes ≈øticking in mee, then for the unkindne≈ø≈øe I take at thy ≈øhooting them at mee. As the love with which thou give≈øt, is more deare to mee then thy gifts; ≈øo the anger with which thou ≈øtrike≈øt, is more grievous to mee then thy rod: and alas, O Lord, how can I then chu≈øe but roare through the unquietnes of my heart, when I want both thy gifts, and thy love too, and yet feele thy rod, and thine anger too? Ver≈øe 9 All my de≈øire, O Lord, is ever before thee, and my groaning is not hid from thee: but what availes it mee, that my de≈øire bee all before thee, if it be not all for thee? what avails it mee, that my groaning be not hid from thee, if it be not made to thee? If I de≈øire any thing be≈øides thee, that de≈øire is from weakne≈ø≈øe, and then thou regarde≈øt it not; if I groane to any but thee, that groaning is from vainne≈ø≈øe, and then thou ≈øee≈øt it not: but now that my de≈øire is onely for thee, and my groaning onely to thee; now I know, thou both ≈øee≈øt and regarde≈øt

But, alas, O Lord, Ver≈øe 10 this is not yet the whole chapter of my mi≈øery; for be≈øides this, My heart panteth, my ≈øtrength faileth mee; and as for the light of mine eyes, that al≈øo is gone from me. My heart is not wont to pant, but in ≈øome great agonie; nor my ≈øtrength to ≈øayle, but in ≈øome great conflict; nor my ≈øight to goe from mee, but in ≈øome great di≈øa≈øter: how great then, alas, mu≈øt my agonie bee, how hard my conflict, how grievous my di≈øa≈øter; when my heart, my ≈øtrength, my ≈øight, all ≈øayle mee at once? It is ≈øome comfort to men in mi≈øery, when
they have their friends about them; if not to relieve them, yet at lea≈øt to pitty them: for even pitty, is a comfort to men in mi≈øery: but ≈øo mi≈øerable am I, that I am left alone, as one utterly for≈øaken. Yet it is not ≈øo much mee they ≈øtand aloofe from, as my ≈øore; for if it were not for my ≈øore, I ≈øhould have enough of their company, ea≈øily enough: but they cannot abide ≈øores, their eies are too tender to endure to ≈øee them, and yet hard enough, not to relieve them. Or is it they ≈øtand aloofe, that is ≈øo neere, as to ≈øhew, they are willing enough to ≈øee them; but yet ≈øo farre off, as to ≈øhew, they have no meaning to come and helpe them. But call you the≈øe lovers and friends? Men that flutter about us like flies, in the Summer of pro≈øperity, but vani≈øh and are gone in the winter of adver≈øity? Are friends but painted flowers, onely for ≈øhew, and nothing at all for u≈øe? Or if true flowers, yet onely to make no≈øegayes of, and never to make medicine of? Is there u≈øe of Phy≈øitians but when there are ≈øores; and when ≈øores come, will not they bee gotten to come? comes with a band of men, ≈øcar≈øe a man found that will bee gotten to tarry: and if they u≈øed the Ma≈øter ≈øo, can I that am a ≈øervant, looke to bee better u≈øed?

But ≈øay, you call them friends, yet how can you call them lovers? for it is the nature of love, to bee readie≈øt at hand, when there bee troubles at hand. Doth not the Elme, alover of the Vine, ≈øupport the Vine, when it el≈øe would ≈øinke downe and fall to the ground? doth not the Vine ≈øtick clo≈øe to the Elme, and if the Elm chance to fall, chu≈øeth rather to fall with it, then to for≈øake it? And ≈øhall nature doe this in trees, and ≈øhall not rea≈øon, ≈øhall not vertue, do it much more in men? or ≈øhall trees bee reckoned the rea≈øonable Creatures, and men bee ca≈øhiered out of the number? But this is the world; they are called lovers and friends, of their faces, no otherwi≈øe then Baboones may bee called men: for when a day of triall comes, they are often found as farre from friend≈øhip and true love, as Baboones from rea≈øon, and true under≈øtanding.
